executiveSummary:
Results reflect actuals through the last completed whole month (December 2025); all periods beyond this are forecast.

  • Momentum: ARR is £9.4m, up 70% YoY, ahead of budget (+11% ARR vs plan). Rule of 40 at 63% and strong CAC efficiency (0.56) indicate healthy growth efficiency.
  • Profit path: Gross margin steady at 78%. EBIT is -7% now but improves to positive from mid-2026 on the current plan as operating leverage builds.
  • Retention is the constraint: NRR has trended down to ~90% on a rolling 12 months, with gross retention at 79% vs a 91% benchmark. The last 3 months delivered net +£506k ARR but included £405k churn (4 logos), concentrated in Finance & Professional Services and Africa.
  • Where wins are coming from: Energy & Utilities and North America led new/expand in the quarter; additions and land are the main drivers ahead of plan, while upsell underperformed vs budget.
  • Capital allocation: S&M spend is elevated at 37% of revenue (vs 32% benchmark); Development is 28% (below 33% benchmark). Given retention headwinds, prioritizing customer success and product depth in at-risk segments should raise NRR toward/above 100%.

Immediate actions

  • Launch targeted save/expansion plays in Finance & Professional Services and Africa; assign exec sponsors to top-10 at-risk accounts.
  • Stand up a Q1/Q2 upsell program to close the budget gap in expansions; use Energy & Utilities playbooks where win rates are strongest.
  • Rebalance spend modestly from S&M to CS/Product for 2 quarters to lift NRR; hold CAC at or below 0.60.
  • Codify a churn early-warning system from the last-3-months patterns; set a board KPI of NRR ≥ 100% by Q4 2026.
page1:
Dashboard

  • Scale & growth: ARR £9.4m across 96 customers; average ARR/customer £98k. ARR growth 70% vs 19% benchmark — strong market fit.
  • Quality of revenue: Recurring mix 94% (above 90% benchmark). Gross margin 78% and recurring margin 83% are solid.
  • Efficiency: Rule of 40 at 63% and ARR per head 147 (vs 77 benchmark) show productive scaling. CAC ratio 0.56 with LTV:CAC 6.5 is attractive.
  • Pressure point: Logo retention 85%, gross retention 79%, net retention 90% — all below benchmarks (91%/101%). This is the key limiter to compounding.
  • Spend mix: S&M 37% of revenue (above 32% benchmark) while Development 28% (below 33%). Rebalancing toward post-sale success and product depth should help NRR.
  • Profitability: EBIT -7% (slightly below -6% benchmark); improving trajectory expected as growth continues and retention improves.

Actions

  • Set a 2-quarter plan to raise NRR to ≥95% (milestone) and ≥100% by Q4 2026.
  • Shift 2–3 pts of spend from S&M to CS/Product without harming CAC; protect gross margin ≥78%.
page2:
Logos, ARR and Deals

  • Logo dynamics: December 2025 shows 8 new logos and 4 lost over the quarter; cumulative logos at 96, on track to scale to 168 by end-2027. Near-term logo retention is 96% in the period view, but the rolling metric on the Dashboard is lower (85%) — indicating recent improvement that must be sustained.
  • ARR engine: For the quarter ending December 2025: Land £720k, Expand £236k, Downsell -£45k, Attrition -£405k → ARR Net +£506k. This pattern matches the 12‑month waterfall: strong additions (£4.41m) offset by elevated losses (-£0.88m) and modest downsell (-£0.27m).
  • Conversion to pipeline: Deals volume (1,107 in Dec 2025) remains healthy; ensure post-sale coverage scales in step with logo growth to prevent lagging NRR.
  • Outlook: Forecast builds ARR to £11.1m by Dec 2026 and £17.6m by Dec 2027 with improving retention metrics. Hitting the plan depends on keeping logo losses at or below forecast and increasing expansion rate from current levels.

Actions

  • Institutionalize a land-to-expand motion within 90 days of go-live to lift expansions per logo cohort.
  • Use churn learnings from the last 3 months (see ARR transactions) to update ICP disqualification and success plans.
page3:
P&L and Headcount

  • Topline & margins: Dec 2025 revenue £8.38m; gross margin £6.58m (78%). Margin is stable across the plan, supporting operating leverage.
  • OpEx mix: S&M £3.10m (37%), Development £2.36m (28%), G&A £1.71m (20%). S&M is high vs benchmark and Dev is low, consistent with NRR headwinds.
  • Profit trajectory: EBIT -£0.60m (-7%) at Dec 2025; crosses to positive by Jun 2026 and reaches ~6% by Dec 2027 as revenue scales to £15.8m with OpEx growth moderating.
  • Unit economics: CAC ratio ~0.56–0.65 across periods; LTV:CAC dips to 6.5 now, recovering to ~9.7 by 2027 assuming retention lifts. This recovery is sensitive to NRR improvements.
  • Headcount: 64 at Dec 2025, rising to 106 by Dec 2027. Largest additions are in Development and S&M. Maintain ARR per head ≥140 while hiring.

Actions

  • Reallocate 1–2 FTEs/quarter to Customer Success and in-product adoption to reduce time-to-value and churn.
  • Introduce margin gates on S&M programs (CAC payback ≤12 months equivalent given our ratios) to preserve Rule of 40 ≥60%.
page4:
ARR

  • Where ARR sits: By vertical — Energy & Utilities £3.95m (largest), Life Science £2.50m, Government £1.31m, Finance & Professional Services £0.90m, 3rd Sector & Education £0.77m. By country — South America £2.18m, Asia £2.09m, North America £1.87m, Africa £1.86m, Europe £1.42m.
  • Growth vs resilience: 12‑month ARR growth is 70% driven primarily by Land (£4.41m) with modest Expand (£0.62m). NRR rolled down from 114% to ~90% over the year, signaling rising churn/downsells in several geographies.
  • Retention by segment: Energy & Utilities and Life Sciences show stronger net percentages vs Finance & Professional Services, which exhibits weaker retention (also reflected in last‑3‑month losses).
  • Concentration: Top accounts drive meaningful monthly swings (ARR per customer grid). Several churn/reductions in Oct–Dec appear in a small set of customers, elevating concentration risk.

Actions

  • Double‑down sales capacity and references in Energy & Utilities; replicate its onboarding and expansion playbook to Government and North America.
  • For Finance & Professional Services: targeted roadmap commitments and executive QBRs for top 10 accounts; tie feature delivery to renewal milestones.
  • Install segment‑level NRR targets and owner accountability (vertical leads) with monthly variance reviews.
page5:
ARR transactions last 3 months

  • Net impact: +£506k ARR and +4 logos for Oct–Dec 2025: New £720k (8 logos), Expand £236k, Downsell -£45k, Lost -£405k (4 logos).
  • By vertical: Strength in Energy & Utilities (+£461k) and Government (+£135k). Finance & Professional Services -£360k net, indicating product/fit or value realization issues.
  • By country: North America +£315k and South America +£135k led growth; Africa -£34k net due to concentrated churn.
  • Customer signals: Losses centered on a handful of accounts (e.g., -£90k and -£135k events) plus a -£45k downsell. Expansions/new lands are broadly distributed but smaller per logo than the losses.

Immediate actions (next 60–90 days)

  • Create save plays for at‑risk Finance & Professional Services logos and African deployments: exec outreach, usage recovery plans, pricing flexibility tied to adoption milestones.
  • Raise average expansion per happy customer: bundle analytics/automation add‑ons and annual‑prepay incentives; set a quarterly target to lift average expand/expansion logo by 20%.
  • Churn post‑mortems within 10 business days; feed learnings to ICP and deal qualification. Flag use‑case misfit early in sales cycle.
page6:
Budget Analysis

  • Annual performance vs budget (2025): Revenue +£122k (+1%); Gross margin -£80k (-1%); Overheads favourable in S&M (+£405k) and G&A (+£468k), partially offset by Development (-£68k). EBITDA -£595k vs -£625k plan — £30k better.
  • Quarter to date: Latest quarter EBITDA -£53k vs -£128k plan (£76k better) on stronger margin and lower S&M.
  • Month latest: EBITDA -£36k vs -£54k plan (£18k better), indicating improving run‑rate.
  • ARR vs budget: Total additions +£329k (8% ahead), attrition £115k better than plan, downsell £22k worse, upsell £41k below plan. Net ARR +£382k (+11%). Growth is landing‑led; upsell is the largest variance to close.

Actions

  • Protect the EBITDA beat by keeping S&M below plan while reallocating selectively to CS/Product to lift NRR — aim for GM ≥78% and CAC ≤0.60.
  • Launch an upsell sprint (price packs, tier upgrades, usage‑based add‑ons) to recover the -£41k variance and raise FY26 expansion trajectory.
  • Institutionalize monthly budget-to-actuals at the segment level (vertical x geo) to catch churn clusters early and adjust investment.
